many thanks!  it seems, regarding grain, that some was extremely  
tight and "un-obvious" so to speak.  will load targeted pix shortly I  
hope...

fred, as well, is a very helpful man, and generous with his time.

cheers,

dw



On Feb 4, 2009, at 3:12 PM, excelsiorilluminati wrote:

> Impossible to comment without good pictures of what you refer to. If
> you see no grain in the hada it is certainly an indication it is
> machine made, if the polish is good enough to tell. The hamon of a
> machine made blade when oil quenched shows lack of activity, a clue.
> Focus your pics on the nakago and mei for appraisal. Fred knows his
> stuff so he is probably right. John
>
> --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "D. Christian Walsh"
> <pixwords@...> wrote:
> >
> > hello -
> >
> > I'm new to nihonto, so please be kind!
> >
> > I've acquired an interesting shin gunto with the following
> traits:
> >
> > - tang signed nakata sukehori, according to fred. weissberg
> > - black lacquered (not painted) wooden saya with field cover in
> fine pigskin; ink stamps
> > inside
> > - a fine mirror-polish blade with good, continuous ("active"?) hamon
> > - tsuba hole for the release button, but button missing; (the
> circular piece above the
> > grip is late-war and lacks this feature)
> > - grip has typical WWII furniture.
> >
> > so some basic questions::
> >
> > * what's the chance that this is the "old" goto sukehori and not
> nakata?
> > * how to distinguish machine-made from hand-made blade?
> > * why would sukehori sign a machine-made blade?
> > * with an 8-power loupe I detect no "grain." proof of a machine-
> made blade?
> > * the very edge of the blade seems to have sharpening (very thin -
> ca. 1/16"). Is this
> > as I hope the original edge?
> > * could the saya be an old one since it's lacquered?
> > * since the grip still has the sharkskin, safe to assume it's late
> but not VERY late war
> > (when fishskin was abandoned)?
> > * the field cover seems to have shrunk over the saya. I'd like to
> see the scabbard in its
> > glory. but - best leave alone?
> > * are the stamps in the saya cover more likely inspectors' or
> owner's?
> >
> > many thanks for the patience and help with these queries!
> >
> > I'll try to load a few pix....
> >
>
>
>
